item.title: Free Myers Briggs Type Indicator MBTI Test
item.description: The MBTI stands for Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. It is an assessment of personality based on questions about a person’s preferences in four domains: focusing outward or inward; attending to sensory information or adding interpretation; deciding by logic or by situation; and making judgments or remaining open to information1.

item.title: Famous People and Their Myers-Briggs Personality Types—Part 1: The Extraverts
item.description: In recent years, Myers-Briggs experts have analyzed many famous people to make educated guesses of their personality types. While most celebrities, past and present, have never taken a personality test, psychologists who are knowledgeable about typology believe they know what the outcomes would be.

item.title: INFJ meets ENTJ
item.description: INFJs and ENTJs are on the same wavelength in many ways. They enjoy spending time together and sharing creative, stimulating conversations.

item.title: Extraverted Disney Characters and Their Personality Types: Part 2 of a Two-Part Series
item.description: Why do we love Disney characters so much? What is it about their stories that touches our hearts? We see reflections of own personalities in characters like Jiminy Cricket, Alice in Wonderland, Pocahontas, and even Merlin.

item.title: Famous Infjs The Good And The Evil!
item.description: Famous Good amd Evil INFJ people INFJ is one of the 16 personality types identified by the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI).

item.title: Introverted Disney Characters and Their Personality Types: Part 1 of a Two-Part Series
item.description: Introverted Disney Characters and Their Personality Types: Part 1 of a Two-Part Series Why do Disney characters hold such a special place in our hearts?

item.title: Extroverted Animals And Their Myers Briggs Personality Types!
item.description: The Extroverted Myers-Briggs Personality Type: Animals, Traits, and Identification The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) is a popular psychological assessment tool that categorizes individuals into 16 distinct personality types based on their preferences and tendencies.

item.title: Introverted Reserved Animals and their myers briggs personality types
item.description: The Introverted Myers Briggs Personality : Shy And Quiet Type Exploring Animal Examples and Identifying Traits The Myers Briggs Personality Type Indicator (MBTI) is a popular tool used to categorize individuals based on their psychological preferences.

item.title: Who Was Donald Trump’s Mother? Mary Anne MacLeod Trump
item.description: The Foundations of Greatness: Exploring the Early Life and Background of Donald Trump’s Parents The story of a prominent figure often finds its roots in the experiences and influences of their parents.

item.title: INFJ Meets ISTJ
item.description: It’s fair to say that any two people with this combination of Myers-Briggs traits are likely to have adjustment problems if they’re to function smoothly together.

item.title: Career Distribution by Myers-Briggs Type
item.description: A 14-year study of thousands of Americans in various careers shows that different Myers-Biggs types have different preferences and skills relating to the jobs they take.

item.title: Depression Profiles—INFJ vs. INFP
item.description: The Myers-Briggs types INFJ and INFP are affected by depression more than most other types. Both are Introverted (I), intuitive (N), and feeling (F).

item.title: Famous People and Their Myers-Briggs Personality Types: Part 2, the Introverts
item.description: The Myers-Briggs personality test has been used to analyze many famous people. While most celebrities, past and present, have never taken a personality test, psychologists who are knowledgeable about typology believe they know what the outcomes would be.

item.title: INFJ Meets ESFJ
item.description: When an INFJ and ESFJ are drawn to each other, the attraction becomes obvious fairly quickly— although the ESFJ is usually the more transparent of the two and is likely to make the first overtures.

item.title: INFJ Meets ESFP
item.description: What happens when an INFJ meets an ESFP? Is there an instant attraction? Do they repel each other like two magnets?

item.title: INFJ Meets ESTJ
item.description: All things considered, the attraction between the ESTJs and INFJs isn’t surprising. Because ESTJs are conventional people, they prefer colorful partners to make their lives more interesting.

item.title: INFJ meets INTP
item.description: INFJs are often drawn to INTPs because of their intelligence and ability to apply logic to every situation. Eventually, though, INFJs tend to find most INTPs distant because of their unemotional approach to life.

item.title: INFJ meets ISFJ
item.description: INFJs and ISFJs are alike in many ways. They’re introverted, feeling, and judging. They differ only on the intuitive/sensing dimension of the Myers-Briggs Inventory.

item.title: INFJ Meets ISFP
item.description: As one of sixteen Myers-Briggs types, the INFJ is introverted (I), intuitive (N), feeling (F), and judging (J). A little different from the ISFP—who shares the introverted (I) and feeling (F) traits but not the intuitive (N) and judging (J) traits.

item.title: INFJ Meets ISTP
item.description: It’s obvious looking at the letters I-N-F-J and I-S-T-P that these two Myers-Briggs personality types are very different. The only trait they have in common is their introversion.

item.title: INFJ Men as Lovers
item.description: INFJ men are complex, warm, and perceptive. They’re drawn to women who are intelligent, creative, and compassionate. While few INFJ men ever achieve perfect relationships, they always wish for them.

item.title: INFJ Women as Lovers
item.description: The INFJ female is an intense, passionate woman. She is drawn to the opposite sex, but few of them turn out to be long-term partners because they’re the wrong type.

item.title: INFJs smile
item.description: In days when it seems hard to be an INFJ, it’s worth looking at some of the qualities that come with this Myers-Briggs personality type.

item.title: Is Romance in the Air? INFJ Meets ISFJ
item.description: INFJs and ISFJs are alike in many ways. Both are introverted, feeling, and judging. They differ only on the intuitive/sensing (N/S) dimension of the Myers-Briggs Inventory.

item.title: It’s Hard To Be an INFJ—The Rarest Myers-Briggs Personality Type
item.description: Myers-Briggs Inventory Isabel Myers and her mother, Katharine Briggs—both psychologists— developed the Myers-Briggs Personality Inventory more than fifty years ago.

item.title: It’s Hard To Be an INFJ: The Author’s Personal Story
item.description: Since posting “It’s Hard To Be an INFJ” on this blog, I’ve received hundreds of e-mails from other INFJs. Their main theme has been how disconnected they’ve felt surrounded by extraverts and more sensible, earthbound types.

item.title: Perceiving vs. Judging—The Dating Game
item.description: Perceiving (P) and Judging (J) are a set of opposite traits on the Myers-Briggs Personality Inventory. They are called the attitude traits.

item.title: Sensors vs. Intuitives—The Dating Game
item.description: In the dating game, the Sensing and Intuitive Myers-Briggs preferences can be a source of excitement and, at the same time, confusion.

item.title: Are You a Sensor or an Intuitive?
item.description: More confusion probably exists regarding Sensors (S) and Intuitives (N) than any other type. Extraverts (E) and Introverts (I) are easy to tell apart.

item.title: Droid Addiction
item.description: At an upscale restaurant with two women friends the other night, I watched one play with her android nonstop during dinner.

item.title: Environmental Cost of Meat
item.description: The U.S. could feed 800 million people with grain that livestock consume say Cornell University ecologist researchers. If the grain were exported, it would increase the U.

item.title: Extraverts in Retirement
item.description: With advancing age, their Myers-Briggs personality scores of people can change, but not by much. Extreme scores on one or more traits tend to soften and move toward the middle.

item.title: Finally, an Updated Version of the Big Book of AA for Today’s Reader
item.description: The EZ Big Book of Alcoholics Anonymous is a paragraph by paragraph “translation” of the original Alcoholics Anonymous—known to AA members as the Big Book—published by AA founder Bill Wilson in the 1930s.

item.title: How To Seduce an INFJ Woman
item.description: The way that men and women express themselves in love matches differs widely. Much of the difference can be traced back to Myers-Briggs type.

item.title: INFJ Meets ENFJ
item.description: People of the INFJ and ENFJ Myers-Briggs types usually make compatible friends and partners. It makes sense when you look at their shared traits: intuition, feeling, and judging.

item.title: INFJ Meets ENTP
item.description: INFJs usually get along well with ENTPs. This may be surprising when one considers that they have only one Myers-Briggs trait in common—intuition (N).

item.title: INFJ Meets ESTP
item.description: When an INFJ meets an ESTP, some special chemistry must be at work for them to enjoy time together. These Myers-Briggs types are exact opposites.

item.title: INFJ Meets INFP
item.description: INFP (introverted-intuitive-feeling-perceiving) and INFJ (introverted-intuitive-feeling-judging) types are a lot alike. They have rich inner lives and treasure their solitude. Also, their intuition is highly developed, giving them the ability to see what’s going on under the surface.

item.title: Introverts at Risk
item.description: Each of the sixteen Myers-Briggs types is unique and different. Some types are outgoing and gregarious, while others treasure their privacy.

item.title: Is Romance in the Air? INFJ Meets INFP
item.description: INFP and INFJ types are alike in many ways. Both types are introverted (I), intuitive (N), and feeling (F). They have rich inner lives and treasure their solitude.

item.title: Is Romance in the Air? INFJ Meets ENFP
item.description: Myers-Briggs personality traits have a lot to do with the potential for romance, friendship, and working relationships. They’re important in family life, too.

item.title: Is Romance in the Air? INFJ Meets INFJ
item.description: When two INFJs find each other, they’re lucky. After all, only one percent of the population is the INFJ type.

item.title: Is Romance in the Air? INFJ Meets ISTP
item.description: If you’re an INFJ, you may find yourself drawn to ISTPs. They’re quietly competent, people of few words who make every utterance worth listening to.

item.title: Johari’s Window
item.description: The Johari Window is a psychological model that was designed for use in self-help groups to help members become more intimate with their peers, while at the same time learning to become more honest with themselves.

item.title: Myers-Briggs Personality Types of Children—Extraverted Kids
item.description: Do children’s personalities remain consistent over the years? If they’re happy babies, will they be happy adults? Or do experiences early in life play a major role in what they become?

item.title: Myers-Briggs Personality Types of Children—Part 1: Introverted Kids
item.description: If your baby comes home from the hospital quiet and easy-going, will the peace last? What about the toddler who enjoys nothing more than turning the pages of a book, while another is scaling every surface in sight?

item.title: New Gainesville Ketamine Infusion Clinic
item.description: Exploring Shy and Introvert Disney Characters: A Journey Through the Quiet and Reserved Florida Mind Health Center for Ketamine Therapy is Gainesville’s new—and only—ketamine infusion therapy center.

item.title: New Year’s Resolutions for INFJs
item.description: We INFJs, like the other fifteen Myers-Briggs types, have our weak spots—vulnerabilities that sometimes bring us into conflict with others or cause personal problems.

item.title: Prevalence of INFJs in the General Population
item.description: According to researchers, the INFJ Myers-Briggs type occurs in about 1% of the population—the lowest prevalence of any type. Studies vary regarding the exact percentages of the 16 types, but INFJs always walk away with the prize for the most rare.

item.title: PSTD in INFJ Women After Sexual Assault
item.description: Several readers have asked whether INFJ women are more prone than other Myers-Briggs types to getting PTSD after sexual assault.

item.title: Tanja Askani–Creator of the New Bambi and Thumper
item.description: Return of Bambi and Thumper Tanja Askani, a Czech author, photographer, and animal scientist living in Germany, has disseminated a series of Bambi-Thumper photos that have gone viral on the internet.

item.title: The Blame Game
item.description: Are you prone to playing the “blame game” when something goes wrong in your life? Do you have friends or relatives who do it?

item.title: The Lord’s Prayer in A.A. Meetings
item.description: In my AA home group, we start meetings by reading from the Big Book: “AA is not allied with any sect, denomination, politics, organization, or institution.

item.title: Timex or Rolex?
item.description: Timex, hands down. Please understand, I don’t have a grudge against Rolex watches because I can’t afford one–although, at an average price of $8000, it would pinch a little.

item.title: Tom Waits, I Love You
item.description: Only this year, after my 78th birthday, did I discover Tom Waits. Now I’m in love and it’s too late.

item.title: Unconditional Love
item.description: Animals are such agreeable friends. They ask no questions. They pass no criticisms. —George Eliot If you have a dog or cat you’re close to, you know what unconditional love is.

item.title: When INFJs Go Bad
item.description: When INFJs are on track, they’re creative and insightful. They’re almost clairvoyant. In addition, they’re compassionate and generous. They are protectors of the weak.

item.title: Your Study Habits
item.description: In fifty years of solitary work—researching and writing—I’ve discovered that some environments put me in a more productive frame of mind than others.

item.title: What Makes Him Want Only You
item.description: Do you ever get a gut feeling about someone the instant you meet them? When that happens, you know it’s not because of what they said or did.
